Tradition
The late autumn winds
knifed through his overcoat,
but warmed by his thoughts,
the alumnus paid no heed, as
he stood meditating in front
of Gilman Hall.
He was reliving the clay—
more than a decade ago—
when he had first stood before
these same Gilman doors as a
freshman. He remembered
his envy as the seniors proudly exercised the privilege,
which belongs only to the
Senior, of walking through
the main doorway. And his
hope that one day he, too,
would be able to have that
right. Then those days as a
Freshman, living in terror of
the diversion-seeking Sophomores, always ready to impress the newcomers with the
might and dignity of belonging to the second year class.
And then he in turn became
a Sophomre and thus was
enabled to look disdainfully
at the new men with suddenly
acquired importance. As a
Junior he was torn between
the carefreeness of the Sophomore and the thought that he
would soon be a Senior. And
finally, all too soon, came the
momentous day when he
walked through those portals
—a Senior.
But the booming of the
Gilman clock abruptly carried him back to the present
and he watched the students
hurrying to and from classes
in the coldly brilliant sun.
One of these men, a Sophomore, by the numerals on his
sweater, walked up the steps
and entered Gilman Hall by
the main doorway.
The alumnus turned and
walked slowly away. The late
autumn winds knifed through
his overcoat, and he hunched
his shoulders to escape the
chilling blasts. The day was
no longer bright.
A Hopkins tradition had
been broken.

The interfraternity schedules this
year will be made up on the basis of
last year's results with the view of
making the four divisions in each interfrat league as equal as possible.
As was the case last year, there will
be interfraternity competition in
touch football, basketball, volleyball,
and softball.
Instead of the two divisions in each
league that was the rule previously,
the leagues will be divided into four
sections each. There will then be
four frats in each division and sixteen in each league.
The plan is to have each team play
two games with each of the other
teams in its division, tlie division
winners to play in a round-robin with
the title going to the frat with the
highest percentage.
Organized Last Year
Interfraternity competition was
organized last year by the Department of Physical Training and Athletics under a point system. Fifteen
points were awarded for a win, ten
for a tie, and five for a game played
and lost. A plaque was permanently
awarded the first team in each sport
and a large plaque being made by
Fred Turbyville was won by the frat
having the greatest number of points
for the whole year.
The first leg on this big plaque was
won by Sigma Phi Epsilon with 330
points. Phi Sigma Delta, the leader
for practically the entire year, was
nosed out in the last game and fell
back to second place, five points behind the leader.

Tradition
The late autumn winds
knifed through his overcoat,
but warmed by his thoughts,
the alumnus paid no heed, as
he stood meditating in front
of Gilman Hall.
He was reliving the clay—
more than a decade ago—
when he had first stood before
these same Gilman doors as a
freshman. He remembered
his envy as the seniors proudly exercised the privilege,
which belongs only to the
Senior, of walking through
the main doorway. And his
hope that one day he, too,
would be able to have that
right. Then those days as a
Freshman, living in terror of
the diversion-seeking Sophomores, always ready to impress the newcomers with the
might and dignity of belonging to the second year class.
And then he in turn became
a Sophomre and thus was
enabled to look disdainfully
at the new men with suddenly
acquired importance. As a
Junior he was torn between
the carefreeness of the Sophomore and the thought that he
would soon be a Senior. And
finally, all too soon, came the
momentous day when he
walked through those portals
—a Senior.
But the booming of the
Gilman clock abruptly carried him back to the present
and he watched the students
hurrying to and from classes
in the coldly brilliant sun.
One of these men, a Sophomore, by the numerals on his
sweater, walked up the steps
and entered Gilman Hall by
the main doorway.
The alumnus turned and
walked slowly away. The late
autumn winds knifed through
his overcoat, and he hunched
his shoulders to escape the
chilling blasts. The day was
no longer bright.
A Hopkins tradition had
been broken.

‘Athletics For All' Program
Jay Walks
Last Year Declared Success; Frosh Football
To Be Continued,Says Shaffer This Year
_By KEN ZIERLER

Interfrat Plans Like Previous Soccer, Golf, Fencing, HandYear, with Football, Volball, Baseball Make Debut;
leyball, Basketball,Softball
Wrestlers Have Full Card
The interfraternity schedules this
year will be made up on the basis of
last year's results with the view of
making the four divisions in each interfrat league as equal as possible.
As was the case last year, there will
be interfraternity competition in
touch football, basketball, volleyball,
and softball.
Instead of the two divisions in each
league that was the rule previously,
the leagues will be divided into four
sections each. There will then be
four frats in each division and sixteen in each league.
The plan is to have each team play
two games with each of the other
teams in its division, tlie division
winners to play in a round-robin with
the title going to the frat with the
highest percentage.
Organized Last Year
Interfraternity competition was
organized last year by the Department of Physical Training and Athletics under a point system. Fifteen
points were awarded for a win, ten
for a tie, and five for a game played
and lost. A plaque was permanently
awarded the first team in each sport
and a large plaque being made by
Fred Turbyville was won by the frat
having the greatest number of points
for the whole year.
The first leg on this big plaque was
won by Sigma Phi Epsilon with 330
points. Phi Sigma Delta, the leader
for practically the entire year, was
nosed out in the last game and fell
back to second place, five points behind the leader.

With the opening of the University
today, the Department of Physical
Training and Athletics begins its second year under its new plan of athletics for all. Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer,
head of the department, has expressed himself pleasantly surprised
at the success of his program in its
initial year in which about seventyfive per cent of the undergraduates
participated. The goal is one hundred
per cent participation.
To increase the scant hundred who
had previously represented the Hopkins in athletics, the field of sport
covered was increased—new teams
were added to the sports already on
the campus and new sports were added to the Jay repertoire.
Soccer Started
An intercollegiate soccer team was
formed under the masterminding of
Frank Dotterweich, who also tutored
the tyro frosh lacrosse team. A golf
team was gotten up which went
through the season undefeated. Paul
Kais ' fencing squad gave a remarkable account of itself in its first year
at the Hopkins. Bob Owings got the
Blue team in on the revival of Maryland college baseball. The intercollegiate status of Gus Van Sant's pretzelbenders was matured. Finally, a
handball team played three colleges
and hopes to play more this year.
At the same time, the schedule of no
existing team was curtailed on account of the increase in new intercollegiate activity.

The practice, begun last year in
lacrosse, of getting a schedule for a
team whenever enough men come
out to fill a squad, will be continued
in football. Thus there will be a varsity, a junior varsity, and a freshman eleven, each with a schedule of
its own and each fully equipped.
This is sad news to football manager Johnny Macgill, but good news
to that majority that likes to play
the game for the fun there is in it.
